{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3340511,"name":"Scott Pantall","username":"scottpantall","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/scottpantall/{size}/208084_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-22T13:12:12.488Z","cooked":"

My team found this note detection model How to Use the note detection frc 2024 Object Detection API and attempted to run it on a Raspberry Pi using Python. This works great when the Pi is connected to the internet and can use the Inference API! However, when we have it running on our robot, it is not connected to the internet so it doesn’t work.

How are teams successfully using these tools? We tried running the Inference Server locally on the Pi as well but that just made the Pi slow down to a very useless crawl.

I feel like I’m missing something fairly obvious, but since this is my first season I have no idea what that might be.

Typically some kind of hardware acceleration is required for acceptable real-time local performance of ML. Something like a Nvidia Jetson, Orange Pi 5 (GPU accel), or Google Coral.

To use Roboflow Note Detection without an internet connection, you would typically need to download and set up the necessary software or libraries provided by Roboflow for offline use. This might involve downloading a pre-trained model or any required dependencies to your local machine or device. Once everything is set up offline, you can then use the Note Detection functionality without needing an internet connection. However, the specific steps and requirements may vary depending on the implementation and version of Roboflow Note Detection you are using, so it’s best to consult the official documentation or support resources provided by Roboflow for detailed instructions.

Nvidia Jetson, Orange Pi 5 (GPU accel), or Google Coral

I had not yet heard of these things. Thanks!
